Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Historical and contemporary influences on elevational distributions and biodiversity tested in tropical Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The causes of geographical gradients in biodiversity are not well understood, and remain a major scientific challenge. Many physical and biotic factors may influence the evolutionary diversification and species distribution dynamics that result in these gradients. This study examines an elevational gradient of tropical birds in Asia, where functional, genetic, and phylogenetic diversity of organisms are woefully understudied and underlying patterns provide a strong system for testing hypotheses about biodiversity along elevational gradients. The proposed research evaluates both traditional (physiological tolerance, competition, opposing boundaries) and novel (taxon age, adult survival, life history trade-offs) factors that vary along elevational gradients and integrates them with dispersal, genetic structure, and phylogenetic history.

The research partners will share samples and data, and collaborate in cross-disciplinary training of students, in pursuing tests of the proposed hypotheses. This integration will lead to a new mechanistic understanding and conceptual framework for the influence of physical climate gradients and biotic interactions on species distributions and the evolution of diversity. The project will provide extensive opportunities for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, including a unique cross-cultural life experience as well as hands-on educational and field experience. Public outreach includes work with high school students and teachers, museum exhibits, and development of an educational video on tropical bird nesting behaviors. Finally, this project has critical conservation ramifications, as tropical Asian forests are being lost at the fastest rate of any tropical forests in the world, and this research will provide critical information on possible climate change impacts that are of grave concern to extinction risks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project combined ecology, physiology, and molecular genetic reconstruction of genealogy to help understand the evolutionary forces responsible for bird diversity on the Southeast Asian island of Borneo. The work centered on Mt. Kinabalu (4095 m), in the Malaysian state of Sabah, northeast Borneo. Ecologists and physiologists from the University of Montana and National Zoo studied nesting behavior and physiology of Kinabalu’s birds by examining egg development, parental care, food, nestling survival, and body size and shape. Using molecular methods, they also measured dispersal patterns of band-marked nestlings by mapping genetic relationships and locations of family members on the mountain. Meanwhile, molecular systematists at Louisiana State University (LSU) and University of Kansas examined genealogical (phylogenetic and population genetic) relationships among all bird species on Borneo to help assess the historical forces responsible for the composition of bird communities at various elevations on Kinabalu. For example, if most of the species on top of Kinabalu are closely related to one another genetically, then similar ecological characteristics shared by the species through their recent common ancestry explains their ability to survive in the cold, wet environment at high elevation. If the species at high elevation are not closely related to one another, then their different ecological characteristics are allowing them to partition resources, thus avoiding competition for scarce commodities, such as food and protected nesting sites. LSU and Kansas biologists also applied molecular genetic methods to examine the structure of bird populations across all of Borneo to determine if ecological and historical factors occurring on Kinabalu influenced population structure and diversity of birds on the island as a whole.

 

The study discovered that bird communities are increasingly composed of closely related species with increasing elevation, suggesting abiotic factors, like cold and moisture, influence bird community structure more than biotic factors, like competition. Phylogenetic and population genetic comparisons also indicated that the region of Mt. Kinabalu acted as one of several rainforest refuges, preserving habitat critical to tropical birds when most of it disappeared across Southeast Asia during harsh climatic times in the Oligocene (34-23 million years ago), Pliocene (5.3-2.6 mya), and Pleistocene (2.6-0.1 mya). These refuges allowed some ancient rainforest bird lineages to survive to modern times, while most others went extinct. The refuges also fomented new species during the Pliocene and Pleistocene by dividing rainforest populations into small, isolated groups that diverged from one another through lack of interbreeding. Finally, molecular studies showed that montane populations across Borneo exhibit genetic structure consistent with the characteristics of individual species demonstrated by ecological and physiological studies on Mt. Kinabalu. Together, these discoveries added importantly to our understanding of how historical and current ecological forces have worked together to create the remarkable diversity of birds occurring in insular Southeast Asia. They also allow comparison with results of similar studies being conducted in the Andes and Amazon of South America.

 

This project involved numerous postdoctoral, Ph.D., M.S., undergraduate, and even high school students. From LSU, one postdoctoral and eight graduate students participated in field work in Malaysian Borneo, learning important lessons in logistics, politics, and culture required of scientific expeditions in foreign lands. Five graduate students and one high school student also worked on the molecular genetic aspects of the project, developing key skills in cutting edge technology. In addition, students of all ranks from Malaysian and Indonesian institutions (e.g., University of Malaysia, National University of Malaysia, and Museum Zoologicum Bogoriensis) also participated in field aspects of the study alongside American students. So far, at least 21 publications involving these students, plus one Ph.D. dissertation and one M.S. thesis, have been produced from the study. Three more Ph.D. dissertations and several more publications are in the pipeline. Some of the recent publications outline a model explaining rainforest animal and plant diversification on Borneo and the other Greater Sunda Islands. This model, called the Sundaic Pleistocene Rainforest Refuge Hypothesis, will undoubtedly be tested by biogeographers working in insular Southeast Asia for years to come. Finally, the international collaborative nature of the project has setup a strong base for future cooperative research between American, Malaysian, and Indonesian researchers.
